reviewText: Finally, MPI media is releasing the fourth installment of the critically-acclaimed Granada Television "Sherlock Holmes" series on DVD! Suffice it to say these are the finest and most "authentic" productions of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes ever made. Most fans consider the late Jeremy Brett to be the quintessential Holmes, and Edward Hardwicke is a fine actor in his own right and a most excellent Dr. Watson.Sadly, Jeremy Brett was in quite bad health when these final episodes were created and would die several years after. Too bad. He was a gifted actor and should rightly be credited with "bringing to life" one of the 20th Century's most beloved fictional characters.People may quibble about liberties taken here and there with the stories, but for the most part the "Casebook" series, like all the others, is very high quality, well-written, produced, and acted. Again, I'm anticipating techno-files may complain about the "transfer" as they have on past releases, but I believe MPI has done the best they can and the DVD is still FAR superior to owning these on videocassette.Don't purchase these as an introduction to the series, start with the "Adventures of Sherlock Holmes." However, if you're here, its probably because you already own the 3 prior DVD packages, "Adventures," "Feature Film Collection," and "Return," all of which are excellent.Are these worth purchasing? Absolutely. High quality, intelligent, and family-friendly entertainment you can enjoy for a lifetime. Pull out every couple of years to watch them over and share with friends and family.

reviewText: The stories featured in this set are every bit as entertaining and fun as those on "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes" and "The Return of Sherlock Holmes."  Technically, the set is even better.  The picture quality is much higher and isn't grainy like the previous sets.  And the packaging itself is higher quality.  The case doesn't feel like it's going to come apart when you open it.  Jeremy Brett was by far the best Sherlock Holmes.  It is a real treat having these collections on DVD.
summary: A Great Set, Both Artistically and Technically

reviewText: "The Casebook of Sherlock Holmes" is the third installment of Grenada Television's one hour episodes featuring Jeremy Brett as the superlative master sleuth and Edward Hardwicke as his faithful and patient collaborator Dr. Watson.  This DVD set features six episodes, adapted for television from the originals scattered across Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's stories."The Disappearence of Lady Frances Carfax" actually comes from the "His Last Bow" collection and centers on the mysterious disappearance of a gentlewoman from a lakeside resort.  Dr. Watson carries much of the load in this case for a mostly off-screen Sherlock Holmes.  "The Problem of Thor Bridge", "The Adventure of Shoscombe Old Place", and "The Illustrious Client", all from "The Casebook", are classic and fairly straightforward cases of detection in the best Holmes tradition.  "The Boscombe Valley Mystery", from "The Adventures", concerns a murder perhaps motivated by the mysterious past of two men in Australia.  "The Creeping Man", also from "The Casebook", may be the most unique story of this series.  Holmes investigates the strange case of a mysterious simian creature menacing the inhabitants of a country home.  As presented, it is something more of a horror story than a straight-up tale of detection.Jeremy Brett and Edward Hardwicke are old hands at their increasingly nuanced partnership as Holmes and Watson by this series.  As the stories bring out, Holmes depends on having an audience in Watson and ocassionally imposes on that long-suffering and loyal gentleman.  The disease that would ultimately take Jeremy Brett's life has by this series made him look increasingly haggard and begun to erode his screen time and energy.  Fans can rest assured, however, that Brett's characterization of Holmes continues to be absolutely first-rate.This DVD collection is very highly recommended to fans of the Grenada Television series on Sherlock Holmes.

reviewText: as i believe i've made clear in other reviews, i am second to none is Sherlock fanaticism, so i'm naturally a fan of the legendary Jeremy Brett series. but alas, even the best series runs out of steam at some point. i'm not suggesting the series is completely valueless from here on (that it "jumps the shark," as we Americans say), but it does come pretty close. this could well be my least favorite period of the series.(i realize most would cite the following season, consisting of three movie-length tales. but while two of those were indeed highly ill-advised, "The Master Blackmailer" - their version of "The Adventure Of Charles Augustus Milverton" - was a distinct highlight for the series. so, disappointing as the other two efforts were, i'm too thankful for "Blackmailer" to write the venture off as a complete failure.)one early blow from which the series never entirely recovered, of course, is it's trading-down of Watsons. David Burke, from the first incarnation of the series, THE ADVENTURES OF SHERLOCK HOLMES, is quite possibly the absolute pinnacle, the single finest Watson we're ever likely to see. more than anyone else, Burke mastered the balance: he could be a step or two behind Sherlock without coming off as a completely hopeless moron. he could bumble a' la Nigel Bruce without degenerating into complete buffoonery. the good Doctor's "everyman" quality has proven a trickier balance that you might think, and Burke did it better than anyone. (although i must confess, that Martin Freeman is coming pretty damn close these days.)the reason(s) Burke left tend to fluctuate - anything from an offer to join The Royal Shakespearean Company to a simple desire to spend more time with his family - depending upon who's telling the story. but either way he walked and the damage was done. his replacement, Edward Hardwicke, plays an exact antithesis of Nigel Bruce. too exact. his sourpuss bureaucrat take on the role is, if anything, even farther removed from Doyle's blueprint. (say what you will about Bruce, at least he brought some WARMTH to the part.) in a way it was "The Dr. Watson Effect" in reverse: Burke had endeared us to that weirdo Sherlock, and now it's Sherlock's turn to persuade us to accept a cold, stuffy new Watson.what's more, Hardwicke may of been something of a prima donna, given the amount of dialogue he managed to pilfer from Brett. to be fair, the same thing had happened occasionally with Burke (it being one way to give Watson a slightly more active role), but when Hardwicke signed on it went from an intermittent trickle to a mass exodus. so much so, in fact, that on two occasions he managed to usurp an entire speech which you don't have to of read the book to know was tailored to Sherlock. in his first appearance, "The Empty House," it is Watson who explains why Colonel Moran killed Ronald Adair...despite there being no earthly reason for him to know. later, when they did the titanic Baker Street showdown with Charles Augustus Milverton, Watson does all the talking...again for no more readily apparent reason that one actor's ego.but that's not the major issue here. they'd had a couple years to iron that out as best they could. truth to tell, Hardwicke does keep that ego in check for the most part here, and he's not such a terrible Watson when he manages to remember his place. still unexceptional, mind you, just not terrible.no, if you wanted to cite the real weakness here, it'd be the fact that they'd already done most of Doyle's better stories. this year they center on ho-hum affairs like "The Boscome Valley Mystery" and "The Disappearance Of Lady Frances Carfax." (although curiously, they weren't quite reduced to that yet. two of my very favorites, "The Dying Detective" and "The Red Circle," would appear in the final season, THE MEMOIRS OF SHERLOCK HOLMES.)"The Creeping Man" is pretty good, although some would argue that it's borderline science-fiction plot is out of place here."Shoscombe Old Place," Doyle's final Sherlock story, is just palatable enough. the episode is interesting chiefly for an appearance by Jude Law, a couple decades or so before becoming Robert Downey's Dr. Watson.i'd probably cite the high point as "The Illustrious Client," but only because of it's uniquely chilling villain, literal ladykiller Baron Gruner. this dude would make Moriarty cringe!! but truth to tell, the promising character is wasted on a rather prosaic story. also, his latest prey is frankly such a bitch that it takes an effort not to root for Gruner so she gets her comeuppance. (even Sherlock expresses temptations leaning in that direction.)you get the idea. it's good (or maybe i should say interesting) enough for us completionists. but i wouldn't recommend it as the introduction for the uninitiated. sad but true, Sherlock is in a bit of a slump here.
summary: The Game Is Still (Sort Of) Afoot!!

A must have for Holme's fans or anyone mildly curious about the great character.

reviewText: Perhaps Basil Rathbone was the quintessential Holmes for the 1930s and '40s, but, I believe that Jeremy Brett will be noted in the history of video productions as the best of the best Holmes.  Quixotic, mercurial in temperment, a slight hint of mental aberation combined with obsessive compulsiveness, and a mysoginistic bent - all are portrayed to perfection.With outstanding technical direction and cinematography, the films are a feast for the eyes.  London of the 1890's, the height of the Victorian era, is shown in it's rigid class structure - slendor at the top, squalor at the bottom - and Holmes gleefully burrowing through it all to find the culprit.Refreshingly astute after the portayal as a bumbling, if kindly, semi-idiot by Nigel Bruce, David Burke and, later, Edward Hardwicke, portray Holmes' able companion, Dr. Watson, as thoughtful, concerned, able and an intelligent friend.I have been watching the Granada films for over 20 years and Holmes movies for over 50 (Could it be that long?).  Holmes movies have always been good to watch.  Brett makes them great to watch.  His passing closed a wonderful, and hard to match, chapter in the book of Holmes portrayals.Watch all of the Granada Holmes films and revel in the excitement, pagentry, and sheer enjoyment of excellence.

reviewText: I have all the videos of Jeremy Brett portraying Sherlock Holmes.  This episode is one of the better stories.  Holmes is hired by a wealthy, incredibly arrogant man to assist the young woman who is the tutor/governess to the man's young children.  The young woman is accused of murdering the wealthy man's wife.  Holmes must review the facts quickly, as time is very limited.  The suspense builds to a nifty climax.  If you enjoy Sherlock Holmes- get this video.  Jeremy Brett is superb.
summary: Holmes finds the Answer at Thor Bridge

reviewText: Having,over the years read all the Sherlock Holmes stories,my opinion is that Jeremy Brett IS Sherlock Holmes,not acting as him.His aquiline features,nervous energy and commanding personality is very close to the mental image of Holmes I pictured when I read the stories.The more recent versions of Holmes,presumably to satisfy our modern audiences,do not portray Holmes the character created by Conan Doyle.Jeremy Brett too must have emotionally identified himself with Holmes since he undertook to act as this charismatic character even when he was terminally ill.Very sorry he passed away.RLK.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am an inveterate SHERLOCK HOLMES fan. I've read the entire canon of 4-novels and 56-short stories repeatedly since I was a child. (I'm 64 now.) The most famous SHERLOCK HOLMES, of course, is Basil Rathbone...he appeared in 13-movies, only one of which were from the original canon, that being THE HOUND OF THE BASKERVILLES. The remaining 12 movies were what are called  'pastiches'...(I may have spelled that word incorrectly)...a pastiche is a story about a character that was not written by the original author. THE CASEBOOK OF SHERLOCK HOLMES, SEASON 1 has the British actor JEREMY BRETT as Sherlock Holmes. Mr. Brett IS Sherlock Holmes...if you compare the original illustrations in THE STRAND magazine where the stories first appeared, you cannot come to any other conclusion. HOWEVER, the best feature of this series is that all the stories follow the original canon almost exactly.  No "Sherlock Holmes in Washington" or any other silliness that used the literature of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle simply to 'make money.'  ALL of the Jeremy Brett performances are from the original canon. I personally prefer David Burke as Watson, but for some reason Mr. Burke appeared in only the first broadcasts of this series. If you're a Sherlock Holmes fan...this is where you can see the stories of Sir Arthur brought to life.
summary: The REAL Sherlock Holmes Stories Brought To Life
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Jeremy Brett series of Sherlock Holmes stories is the best I've seen.  You really get immersed in the culture of the time.  The wardrobe, sets, styles and mannerisms of the actors are all wonderful.  You are transported to another time when people saw the world differently and behaved differently than we do now.  Some of the motivations may seem silly to us now.  But because we are so deep into the morals and manners of that time, we accept it.
